conbody.p: Each CDR corresponds to one event but may contain records related to more than one entity. That is, some attributes encode lists of multiple values. By default, NCC-Policy uses the separators colon (":") and hash tag ("#"). For example, to log an attribute with the name policyCounters, which may have a list of policy counters, the list returned is # separated. Each # means another entry. If each entry happens to be a complex entry, for example, made up of a name (counter1) and value, it is separated by another separator the colon “:”. The separators can be configured to use other characters using the application preferences “CDR Sub-Field Separator1” and “CDR Sub-Field Separator2”. See the NCC-Policy application preferences section in the Global Configuration Guide.
A separate CDR is generated for each event.

note.p: If an IP-CAN session has only the MSISDN in the CCR-I message, both the MSISDN and the IMSI are included in the CDR. NCC searches for IMSI from both the session data and the device and adds the info into the CDR if it is found in either of the two places. However, if the IP-CAN session only has the IMSI in the CCR-I message, only the IMSI is included in the CDR without the MSISDN. NCC only searches for the MSISDN from the session data, not from the device. Therefore, if the CCR-I message does not contain the MSISDN, it is not added to the CDR.
